item.description:
Organizers: Ken Hodges & Tomoko Nakajima

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all questions that are part of the RSVP. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event. If you RSVP from a mobile device the questions may not show up - use a computer to update your RSVP so you can answer them.

Your safety, and the safety of the group, is the most important thing. If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself or others at risk – consider this before you decide to participate.

When you sign up, please wait on Waiting List after answering all the questions. We'll screen hikers first from Q&A page and your profile information. Then, we'll contact you through email that you're welcome to join or not.  When you receive welcome email from us, you can go ahead to make a reservation through AMC 603-466-2727 to stay Carter Notch Hut on March 10th night, then please post your comment "booked hut".  We'll move you to on-going list. We had a big issue 2 years ago when we set up similar event.  So we'll carefully screen participants this time.

 

 

What we're doing

This is a two day backpacking trip (March 10th & 11th) We will carry sleeping bags and food for supper/breakfast to cook at Carter Notch Hut in addition to standard winter hiking gear and lunch for 2 days.

Day1 (March 10th, Sat):

We'll be meeting at Wildcat Ridge Trail TH Parking lot on Rt 16 at 7AM.  We leave some cars there for carspotting and drive other cars to the parking lot on RT 16 which is approx 0.4 miles North from Northern side of IMP Trail TH.  The hiking plan is to hike in IMP Trail, we hike IMP Face(3165 ft), Middle Carter Mtn (4610 ft), South Carter (4430 ft) and Carter Dome (4832 ft), then reach to Carter Notch Hut to finish Day-1 hike.  Cook, eat and sleep well!  It will be about 9.6 miles hike.

If weather is pretty good and trail condition is also good, we may change the plan to include Mt Moriah (4049 ft) by hiking in "Stony Brook Trail".  In this case, total hiking mileage at Day 1 will be  14.3 miles instead of 9.6 miles.  Also, we may have to meet earlier than 7AM.


Day2 (March 11th, Sun):

We'll leave Hut 8AM-ish after breakfast. We will hike the Wildcat Range (Wildcat Mtn (4422 ft), B Peak, C Peak, Wildcat D (4062 ft), E Peak) then hike out to our car spot location to complete 2 days backpacking!   Day 2 total hiking mileage is 5.4 miles.

In total, we cover 5 AMC official 4K footers by 2 days backpacking trip. (or 6 peaks if we decide to include Mt Moriah)

Last year when we hiked at Wildcat Range, it was very icy and we had to use crampons instead of microspikes to go up on ledges at steep section of the trail.  So please be prepared.

 

This is advanced hike because it's winter backpacking trip carrying a heavy backpack. If you don't have any Winter hiking experience or if you don't have winter backpacking gear, please refrain from joining this hike for your safety and others safety.  

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group - This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you. 

Guests are not permitted - all participants must be members of the Random Group of Hikers. This allows us to keep track of and communicate with each person who signs up to participate in our events.

Dogs are not permitted on this backpacking hike since we'll be staying at Hut overnight.

=====

Weather

Mountain weather is subject to rapid changes and extreme conditions. Dangerous weather conditions will cancel - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants a day or two ahead of time. We will assess travel and weather conditions during the hike and make changes to our planned trip as necessary.

  • Click here for current weather conditions

=====

Clothing, Gear, Equipment, and Supplies

Below is a list describing the minimum required items to participate in this event. Hiking safely is about being prepared so that you can respond to an emergency situation or spend a night in the woods if you have to. Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip.

  • Footwear: Waterproof/Insulated winter hiking boots with synthetic or wool socks. Gaiters to keep the snow out of your boots. Mountaineering snowshoes with aggressive teeth for traction while climbing. Mountaineering crampons with 10-12 teeth that strap on are required for this trip - Kahtoola Microspikes or Hillsound Crampons are acceptable as back-up only. Since we won't be using these items all of the time either have space in your pack or a way to secure them to the outside of it. I will update as we get closer to the date if full crampons will be necessary.
  • Clothing: Dress in synthetics, fleece, and/or wool layers to easily regulate body temperature. Make sure your layers fit comfortably over each other. DO NOT WEAR COTTON - while cotton is a great insulator when it is dry, once wet it doesn't dry easily and it rapidly draws heat away from the body.
  • Outerwear: Insulated jacket. Windproof/waterproof shell (with hood) and pants. Make sure your outerwear fits comfortably over all of your other clothing. Fleece/wool hat, balaclava or face shield, neck warmer, and glove liners. Windproof/waterproof over-mittens. Goggles.
  • Food and Water: Bring high-energy snacks, food for lunch - pack extra "just in case". Bring enough water to stay properly hydrated during the trip - use insulated wide-mouth bottles instead of a hydration bladder since the mouthpiece/tube can freeze.  This is backpacking 2 days trip.  So you need to bring Day-1's lunch, supper, Day-2's breakfast, lunch at least.
  • Shelter: Be prepared to spend a night in the woods if you have to. Options include an ultralight tarp, a bivy sack, or an emergency space blanket which packs small and weighs just ounces.  Again, this is backpacking trip.  You need to bring sleeping bag for winter use.  I repeat: Don't bring summer use sleeping bag.
  • Other Essential Gear: Map and compass - don't just bring them know how to use them. Plastic whistle. Headlamp with two sets of spare batteries - lithium work best in colder temperatures. Personal first aid kit with an emergency space blanket. Small pocket knife or multi-purpose tool. Matches or wind-proof lighter and fire starter. Toilet kit (e.g. hand sanitizer, toilet paper and a zip-lock bag to pack out your used personal hygiene items). Sunscreen. Lip balm. Sunglasses. Waterproof cover for your pack.
  • Optional Items: Trekking poles. Camera.

=====

Directions:

Our meeting spot will be the Wildcat Ridge Trail TH Parking Lot on RT16. This is ending point of our hike at Day-2 and we'll spot cars here.  Parking lot is probably closed, but, we can park our cars outside of the closed gate which is off road from RT16.

Click here for directions to the parking lot of Wildcat Ridge Tr TH.


Once you open Google Maps simply change the generic starting point ("Boston, MA") to your own starting point to get customized directions.

While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear and agree to know and follow the Hiker Responsibility Code described at www.hikesafe.com
